column7: >We are students with big ideas for Mars!
column12: >We are a diverse team of graduates, undergraduates, and faculty advisers at Arizona State University. We want to see humans explore and colonize Mars in our lifetimes! To achieve this goal, we began adapting an open source vehicle to aid the construction of a habitat for humans on Mars.
column17:
/>

Todd and the team builds a wood 1/3 scale model of MarsTrac.

""Why does it look like an Erector set?"" Our concept is to reuse a small set of standardized parts to build our vehicle and support systems. This makes our design incredibly redundant without extra complexity, because you only have to retain a smaller set of replacement parts and a simpler maintenance setup.
column19:
/>

(Lucas Blog, Open Source Ecology)

In the future, other machines can be built using the same pieces. We can construct an entire industrial ecology for colonists on Mars! Even using current methods and research, NASA and it's partners have shown you can separate martian soil into metals, and separate the gasses in the martian atmosphere into fuels such as methane.  (See: Sabatier reaction andISRU)

Together, we will turn these basic components into more complex machines, not just tractors and lathes, backhoes, and CNC machines
column20:
but entire support industries for our hypothetical colonists. Learn more on our website.

Where did this idea come from?!
column9:
>Open Source Ecology's Life Trac 6

The above video is the Life Trac 6, the original design for earth-based agriculture developed by Open Source Ecology, a project to redesign the 50 machines all modern society is founded upon. It was our inspiration, and our goal is to adapt and expand this amazing project to the exploration and development of the Red Planet.  

By helping fund our student lead team, you will be helping to push humanity beyond Earth and into being a multi-planet species!
column16:
>What We Need!

We need to raise $16,000 to build the vehicle and do initial testing to improve it. Here is the breakdown:

column1:
What if we don't make our goal?

We are confident we can reach our goal, but if we don't, the collected funds will go towards creating a smaller, remotely operated rover with the same mission.
Why is this important to us?
column3:
/>

Some of the MarsTrac team at Phoenix Comic Con.

This is just a prototype, yes. We’re working with a computer simulation, a 1/3 scale model, and a bunch of  good ol’ dreaming. But your contribution can change that. If we reach our fundraising goal, we can build a full scale prototype that can be driven, tested, and troubleshot. As soon as we build this, we’re taking it out to the Mars Desert Research Station (MDRS) and putting it through its paces.
column5:
/>

Humans to Mars. (NASA)

 MarsTrac itself is a representation of something more, of an ecology of machinery that can be used in the harsh environment of the Martian surface, and be the support infrastructure that future astronauts will absolutely need to be successful in their missions to the red planet.

column1: The goal of MarsTrac is simplicity, something that can be taken apart and put back together with the fewest pieces and directions, that can become interchangeable with the entire collection of technology, and that can be easily produced in the environment without reliance on material from Earth.
column6:
/>

Arizona State University has a fantastic record of building competition and commercial rovers, vehicles and robotics. We are well represented at NASA's Luna robotics competition, and our members have even flown experiments in Zero-Gravity.

column1: Other Ways You Can Help!
column4: >If you find yourself unable to contribute financially, don’t sweat it. Every little bit helps, and every click of our share button more so. The more people who hear about our project, the more people can finance our dream, and the faster we can reach our goal. Word of mouth is the currency of the internet, and in that aspect, everyone is rich. So get out there, slap us onto your Facebook wall, tweet our link, blog, share, and post to get more eyes on this page.

Where did this idea come from?!Open Source Ecology's Life Trac 6The above video is the Life Trac 6, the original design for earth-based agriculture developed by Open Source Ecology, a project to redesign the 50 machines all modern society is founded upon. It was our inspiration, and our goal is to adapt and expand this amazing project to the exploration and development of the Red Planet.  By helping fund our student lead team, you will be helping to push humanity beyond Earth and into being a multi-planet species!What We Need!We need to raise $16,000 to build the vehicle and do initial testing to improve it. Here is the breakdown:
$5000 for the steel frame and hardware. (Hollow rounded square 4x4 steel tubes, bolts and nuts.)
$4000 for our modified ""power cubes"" (Frame, engines, hydraulic pumps, batteries, sockets, switches.)
$3000 for our Hydraulic/Electric system (Tubing, cylinders, connectors, wiring, motors)
$2000 for our Remote Control system ( Control panel, electronic actuators.)
$2000 for the transport  and support fees for the Mars Desert Research Station.

Here's the skinny on the CBB

The Cedartown Biz Builder Program was born out of the Downtown Renaissance Strategic Visioning and Planning Workshop. The Renaissance Workshop, held in the fall of 2013, aimed to spur new growth and excitement in downtown Cedartown, Georgia.

As part of that excitement, a group of volunteers formed with one goal in mind: providing new business owners and budding entrepreneurs with top-notch education to increase their chances of success in the local business market. 

And, voilà, the Cedartown Biz Builder Program was created.

OUR MISSION: Through education of basic business concepts and the ability to provide experienced mentorship, the existing business community and local beginning-stage businesses, will be provided with valuable insight and become more attractive to capital outlets.
column5: >As the plan progressed, we developed an educational

column1: partnership between the City of Cedartown and Georgia Northwestern Technical
College.  Together, the partnership created
a customized curriculum focused on basic business principles of customer
service and basic business planning.
Northwestern Technical College faculty and delivered two nights a week along
with a networking session.  The
networking sessions, designed for class participants to learn and gain
access to local community resources, help to shape their business plans and efforts.

Through our first-year efforts, we have 13 students enrolled. These students fit one of two descriptions: they are current business owners or they have dreams to open a business.

Let's get competitive!

Because we know the root of any successful business is the ability to competitively market and pitch your product, we have created two competitions that our students can voluntarily participate in.
The first competition, called “People’s Choice Award,”
will play out online via a watch and vote system. The prize is $1,000. Students
are not required to participate
column2: however, if they want a shot at the prize

column1: money, they’ll need to pitch their business idea in a three-minute video. The
video will be filmed by the City of Cedartown and uploaded to the City’s
website. [direct URL link coming soon!] A voting system will be published on the site as well so that viewers
can watch the videos and then cast their vote. The presentation receiving the
most votes will win the prize.
Videos will be available for viewing and voting on Oct. 13
at 5 p.m.
The second voluntary competition is patterned after the
popular TV show, “Shark Tank.” [we stress no affiliation with the actual show, we just think it's cool]. Students will pitch their business idea to a
panel of five judges and will be rated on a variety of criteria.
This competition, which also carries a $1,000 prize, is
not open to the general public, rather a select number of seats – 25 – are up
for purchase for $25 each. [see option to purchase at right]. Anyone can purchase a ticket
to the event, but once they are sold out, extra seats will not be released. The
good thing about the ticket charge -- all of it will go
towards prize money and the continuation of the Biz Builders program.
<blockquote><b>LOOKING FORWARD: Our goal is to offer this same program next year to our city's future entrepreneurs and business owners. Classes are tentatively set to begin in
April 2015 and last through October 2015.
Wanna help? We welcome your donation.
$16,000 is needed to help fund the following
costs of the program. <span style=""color: rgb(106, 106, 106)
column5: > Funds raised would pay for the following costs and expenses for the Class of  2014 participants:

column1: ·
Plaques
·
Cash award for the JUDGE'S CHOICE award winner ($1,000)
·
Cash award for the PEOPLE'S CHOICE award winner ($1,000)
·
Class costs incurred to
date
All fundraising monies would be the property
of the City of Cedartown special revenue fund.
Brace for impact!
Your campaign dollars will help fund the well-deserved
accolades for program participation and completion. Everyone likes a little affirmation!  At the same time, we will be providing monies
to help continue the CBB program next year.The ability to help provide a strong
foundation to future home-grown local businesses will help the Cedartown
and Polk County community through increased service
offerings along with an increased business tax base.
<h3><b>Risks &amp
Sometimes, the greatest challenge to any business endeavor
is the ability to take the first step.  The
first step for our participants realizing that their idea or concept has value
and is worth pursuing.  Through their
personal efforts of attending class while balancing existing job or family
obligations, they have set out on the path toward entrepreneurship, building plans for future success with each step.  Even though
well planned with the greatest of intentions and efforts, over 80% of small
businesses fail within the first year.
Your donations help reward the effort for those who have
attended class and wish to open a business right here in Cedartown. At the same time, your dollars
will help others next year reach that same goal of starting their own business and that's very kind of you!
Flat broke? Other Ways You Can Help
Some people just can't contribute, but that doesn't mean you
can't help:
·
Share and like our site on Twitter and Facebook
through the tools below
·
Through the word of mouth, tell others that
Cedartown and Polk County are supporting small business. Tell them about CBB!
·

Shop local in Cedartown and Polk County, keep your money here

For more than 7 years EnglishPAL.ps provides information of all kinds about Palestine. The site's content is non-political and includes anything from leisure over professional life to higher education. Information is pre-filtered and categorized.

Short Summary

 

My name is Gaspare. I'm Italian and passionate with Anglo-American Literature. I graduated in English Literature here in Venice. After that opening an Anglo-American bookshop was rather predicatable...
I did that last November. I work everyday with Venetians willing to read in English, with the Anglo-American expats living in Venice and with tourists from - you can imagine - all over the world.

In a few months my bookstore, I'm happy to say, has already become a reference point in Venice since here there are no other English speaking bookshops !

What We Need &
column2:
What You Get 

Business is going comparatively well, luckily enough. But as you know, book market is not easy and we are really small. To start the business I asked the help of the Italian State (special funds for young entrepreneurs) yet Italian bureaucracy is making me crazy - the funds have been approved of but I've been waiting for them since last November ! So I had to use only my money to open the shop.

column1: We need some help for ordinary expenses, especially to pay off the rent at least for one year. We want to grow and become a big cultural centre here in Venice - we are already doing many things (book launches, book club, cinema at the bookshop through Wellington Nickelodeon, conversations with authors etc.) yet we certainly need a help to bear all the expenses which here in Italy, especially for the first year, are huge.
If we don't reach the goal, all the money we might collect will be anyway invested in the bookshop, in any of our needs, from the rent to light bills etc.

Giving to our pledge you can become a member of our Wellington BooKs-Venice Club, a special group of people who share an interest in Literature, books and Venice. If you come to Venice, you can get books from us with a 50% discount and if you donate a generous amount you'll get a book on Venice as a present  and many other things !

The Impact

 

The existance of an Anglo-American bookshop in Venice is important for some main reasons:
• there is one in every city of art in Italy (Florence, Rome, Milan)
• we are a trait d'union between Italians and English speaking people
• we organise all sorts of cultural events
• we keep not just touristic books but REAL literature
• we are not ruled by chain-bookstore logic
• we are independent
• we are young people with young ideas

Your support is VITAL !

Some of our activities in images:

Books for kids &
column2:
teens

 

Second-hand books - real bargains !

 

WELLINGTON NICKELODEON - cinema at the bookstore (here we are watching a film on the rights of women in Congo).

 

Book Club meeting

 

Our sunny window !

column1: Other Ways You Can Help
If you can't donate that's all right, you can help us in other ways !
First thing, you can spread the voice through social networks such as Facebook, Twitter, Instagram.
You can speak about it to your friends - word of mouth is always the best thing !
And, last but not least, you can LIKE our Facebook page !
https://www.facebook.com/wellingtonbooks.venice
https://www.wellingtonbooksvenice.com

Hi Boston, Cambridge, Somerville, Everett, Malden, Medford

You live near an ocean with decent beaches. Wouldn't it be great if you could hop on your bike and get there easily?

Hi Revere

This is the opportunity for our neighborhood to get its piece of the trail.
column3: >We're working on a critical link in the
column5:
> that will let you bike traffic-free into Boston.

Build it!

Imagine being able to go for a walk with your friends and family on a trail that passes through both convenient urban areas and the open and beautiful Rumney Marsh, and being able to say, ""I built this!""

This is your chance.

Bike to the Sea is a local organization that has been working for 20 years to secure the support and access to build a trail on the right of way of the former Saugus Branch Railroad that goes all the way from Everett near Wellington Station, through Malden, Revere, and Saugus, to the waterfront in Lynn.

Sections of trail in Everett, Malden and Saugus were recently completed, and now we're  working on filling in the missing link through Revere to connect them.

The views and tranquility of the Revere portion of the trail may surprise you, given its proximity to densely settled cities. Previously this area was inaccessible and you might only have been able to get a brief glimpse of it through the windows of a car speeding down Route 1. The creation of the trail may give you a new favorite destination. 

This will also become an integral part of the East Coast Greenway, which is a growing network of off-road paths leading all the way from Maine to Florida. The possibilities for getting outside and going somewhere are endless.

This is your vote

Don't have much money to commit to this? That's okay. We get it. But even putting in a couple dollars makes a huge difference, because it says that this is important to you. That having decent outdoor spaces and ways to get around on foot or on a bike matters, and that once this trail is built, you want it maintained.

Why even a couple bucks is a big deal

There's another reason that even small donations make a big difference. We applied and got awarded a grant of over $116,000 through the Department of Conservation and Recreation, but in order to get that money, we need your help. We have to match at least 20% of the grant money with outside funding. That means that for every dollar you give us, we're allowed to claim an additional five dollars of grant money to reimburse project costs. 

So if you donate $20 here, you're actually making it possible for us to get not just your $20, but also another $100. The contributions you provide are going to make an enormous impact.

What do you get

For a donation of any amount (yes, really, any amount), you can choose to be anonymous, or to get your name listed on the Bike to the Sea website as an expression of our gratitude.

We also have gifts for specific donation levels, as shown on the right side of this page.

If you're a local business looking to play a larger part and potentially have your contribution made visible and permanent on the trail, please contact us. We'd be happy to chat.

What will be built (and when)

A map of the trail route can be seen here.

The Everett and Malden sections were first built with loose granular material in 2012, and then each of those cities saw that the existence of the trail was such a great thing that they were able to find the funding to have their sections paved in 2013. The Saugus section was built with granular material in 2013.

Revere's section of the trail will be built at no cost to the city of Revere, using granular material similar to what's currently in Saugus (or higher quality if we can afford it). Later, if you want it paved or otherwise improved, it'll be helpful to have your voice speaking up in favor of the cause.

Other Ways You Can Help

Even if you don't contribute, that doesn’t mean you can’t help. 

Get the word out for us. Use the links on this page to share via email or facebook. Tell you friends to take a look at this page. If you run a local business and want to put up a flyer pointing to this, let us know, and we'll come up with something good for you.

Short Summary

My name is Lucas but many of you know me or will know me as ""Little Hawk"".  I spent countless hours with my Grandfather ""Hawk"" riding and hanging out in the garage.  As I continue through life, I find that I feel closer to him while riding or servicing my own bike
column2:
and as many people find when they begin riding it becomes a way of life. To help me in this endeavor I am completing a motorcycle service course and am really looking forward to providing this service for others in the area.

I am campaigning to start up a motorcycle service and tire shop.  I will also offer detailing for both bikes and automobiles.  It is important to me to make this a family business and focus on customer satisfaction.  This area needs a motorcycle service shop as currently the closest businesses are dealerships in Beckley or Summersville, but no small time mom and pop shops.

Your contributions will allow me to register the business, obtain a lease on the service building (yes, I have the perfect building ready to move into), and receive insurance for that property.  It will also allow me to purchase equipment, tools and supplies needed to get started properly. 

What We Need &
column3:
What You Get

I have set my campaign goal at $10,000.  This allows me 6 months of lease on the building and associated utilities.  It is also my goal to obtain equipment, tools and supplies that are needed, including:

column1: • Tire Machine and Balancer
• Tires
• Tune-Up Kit
• oils/filters
• Power Washer
• Detailing Supplies
• Office Supplies
• Computer
• Accounting Program

I thank you for any contribution you are able to make and in return would like to provide you something special.  Please take a look at our varying perks for helping us out and please choose one that fits your needs.   We are offering items such as Little Hawk Service Shop t-shirts, gift certificates for services and details, VIP dinner for two at a 5-star restaurant, or even an adventure for two in the New River Gorge.  Check the perks section for more specific details and even more offerings.

Of course we are hoping to reach our entire goal, however, if that is not the case we will use the funds received in the order of importance to get the business going.  We will definitely start with making sure the lease, insurance and utilities are covered.  After that the purchase of the tire machine, balancer and detailing equipment/supplies are next on the list.  Afterwards, we will use the funds to purchase other supplies as the need arises. 

The Impact

All contributions will be used toward starting a much needed service in the Oak Hill area.  Currently the only places to get your bike serviced involves you going to a dealership.  At my shop you will get the small town personal touch focusing on in and out service to get you back to riding.  Our lease also includes a large empty lot across the street that we will be utilizing for events.  Some of our ideas include a poker run, charity events, and motorcycle swap meets among other things.  Stay tuned in the spring we will be hosting a grand opening poker run and inviting other businesses in the area to help build community.

Other Ways You Can Help

I understand that everyone may not be able to contribute and appreciate you taking the time to go through my campaign.  Please help me get the word out, share this through the Indiegogo share tools, on your facebook/Twitter page, send out emails, spread the word, or come see us when we open!  Any other ideas are also welcome, please feel free to email me with your ideas or questions at littlehawkbotw@gmail.com.

Thanks Again and see you on the Road!

Friends of Braksis the Gentle Giant is a not for profit organization whose goal is to help aid and support special needs children and their families with their daily care and development. 

Donations to the organization can be made in any RBC branch in Ontario or online if your already an RBC client. 

If you have any questions, concerns or advice feel free to touch base with Lisa McGee (President) at braksisthegentlegiant@gmail.com. 

For now all donations will help to support Matthew and Connor Lippelt. Sons of Sharron and Mark 'the Gentle Giant' Lippelt. Though we hope in the years to come to extend help to other special needs children and their families. 


History: 

Friends of Braksis the Gentle Giant was founded after the passing of Mark Lippelt. Father of Connor and Matthew Lippelt. For years Mark was a stay at home father acting as a caregiver for the young boys. Connor and Matthew are twin brothers, born with a genetic deficiency of a translocation of chromosome 9 and 10. The Lippelt boys need consistent attention and care.

This group is to help raise money to help the Lippelt boys pay for the care that they need. Our hope is in the years to come to be able to help raise money for other special needs children and their families.

Short Summary

We are post graduate students currently undertaking a project to raise fund for a old folks and orphanage home by the name of "" Pusat Jagaan Beribuan Kasih "" located in kajang . The home had been operated for the past 11 years which minimum help with limited support. The home consisting of 37 children ,senior citizen, infant, disable person and mentally and physically challenge. Range from 2 years to 70 years .  

What We Need &
column2:
What You Get

We need monetary help so that there can purchase the basic need for their daily needs such as food, cloth, medicine and etc..

column1: You may visit them at :
Pusat Jagaan Kanak-kanak Istimeva dan Warge Emas
No 3, Lot 1547 Belakang Taman Bangi, Jalan Reko
43300 Kajang, Selangor Darul Ehsan.

The Impact

No amount is too small and too large . Your sincere each contribution will light up each person in the home. The contribution will solely use to buy basic need of the home.
Risks &
column2:
Challenges

The biggest challenge  is  the sustainability for the home. The major contribution is from the founder, Ms Kavitha . ( She working as a part time nurse at the private hospital )

column1: There  is no regular contribution from the public. Your kind gesture is greatly needed.

Other Ways You Can Help

You can visit the home by yourself and pass them your contribution.
Pusat Jagaan Kanak-kanak Istimeva dan Warge Emas
No 3, Lot 1547 Belakang Taman Bangi, Jalan Reko
43300 Kajang, Selangor Darul Ehsan.

Introduction

People are dying and being severely injured on the dark streets of Costa Rica. Without streetlights or sidewalks people are forced to walk on the street within inches of passing motorists. Reflective arm and ankle bands are a simple, inexpensive solution to this pervasive problem as they help both the pedestrians and drivers. We have created a small, local Women's Collaborative where the woman hand-make and sell Reflective Safety Bands to their community, bringing light to the dark streets of Costa Rica.
column5:
/>

               An iPhone photo with flash is an impressive example of how bright 
                 our Reflective Safety Bands are at night to an oncoming vehicle. 

About Us

column1:
We are a mom, dad, three kids, and (now) two dogs from Boston who moved to the rural, Pacific Coast of Costa Rica in July 2014, simply to see the world through a different lens. Our perspective of life certainly has changed in the short time we’ve lived here. Sure, we now know what it means to live with cows, howler monkeys, chickens, street dogs, and countless varieties of reptiles at our front door. We also now understand why Ticos (the name Costa Rican's call themselves) were recently named the ""Happiest People on Earth.""  Finally, living here has illuminated  how easy it is to take for granted the privileges we have in the US, where our tax dollars ensure the safety and security of our public spaces and residents.  

The Challenge
Road-related fatalities rank fourth in causes of death in Costa Rica. There are three times more pedestrian fatalities than alcohol related accidents in Costa Rica.

column4: > motorists.  It gets dark here by 6:30 pm every night of the year and it's very hard to see what's ahead.
column5: >The roads are narrow,  have no sidewalks, and rarely have any street lights. Nevertheless, the road is the only place to walk.  Jungle on both sides or fear of snakes in the brush keeps everyone on the road.
column6: >Only 18% of age-eligible drivers have a driver’s license. The rest travel by bus, bike, moto, or walk and many assume that because they can see the oncoming cars bright headlights, that the drivers can see them  … but they can’t.

column5:
/>

                            Our friend Keith who lost his leg in a roadside accident.

Debbie had the fortune of spending a week with Keith at a TEFL Training last year where they were certified to teach English as a second language.  Keith was in the training to acquire new skills because he was no longer able to do his previous job. Eighteen months earlier, he was hit by a car at 5:00 am while leaving work in Tamarindo and lost his leg.  He was lucky enough to meet a very generous expat who sponsored his recovery (and TEFL training) and arranged for him to be fitted and treated for a prosthetic leg. Needless to say, this support is not typical of others who have been injured on the local roads. Keith is super supportive of this project and excited to be able to offer the bands to his community. Our goal of this project is to prevent others, like Keith, from being hurt on these dark roads.

column1: Shortly after we moved here, Eli conceived of the idea to create and distribute reflective bands for the people living in the surrounding area.  We are now making this idea a reality.  There are about 3,000 residents in the surrounding towns (Potrero, Flamingo, Brasalito, Huacus, Villa Real, and Matapalo).  We have purchased enough reflective material from the States for a first run of 3,000 bands. Thanks to an introduction by Laetitia Deweer, founder of CEPIA, www.cepiacostarica.org, an incredible non-profit community center here, we have teamed up with some amazing women in the surrounding area, allowing us to start: Proyecto Bandas Reflectantes: Collaboration de Mujeres / Project Reflective Safety Bands: A Women’s Collaborative.
column6:
schema=youtube"" width=""580"">

Meet the people who are making it happen:

These four women have already made almost all 3,000 bands. They are grateful to have this earning opportunity and proud to be contributing from the beginning to a project that will directly impact their community. Listen to Thais' video in the Gallery above (in Spanish).

column1:
Meet the founding members of our Women’s Collaborative:
                                   (From left to right) Ana, Olga, Auyda, and Thais.

Alfonso at HangTen, a local print-shop, has been super helpful in putting instructional information and photos on the bands.  The inside of the bands have photos with and without light and explain: ""Drivers can't see you until they are too close. This band reflects light back to the driver from far away. Wear it on your  wrist or ankle."" The band also has a local WhatsApp number and email encouraging questions, feedback ... and hopefully a request for more bands.

                                                      on the inside of the bands.

column1: <div>

Noah and Nava at Thais's sewing machine.
              On March 8th, the women threw a surprise birthday party for Debbie.
<div>
Distribution Challenge -
have wrestled with how to distribute the Reflective Safety Bands and track the
impact they have on the roads. After much consultation, trial and error, our
initial plan is to give them away for free at the local markets, churches,
schools, on the streets, etc. We have created explanatory displays in English
and Spanish with rings of 40-60 bands attached and have hung them in many bus
stops, markets, and popular road-side areas. We’ve watched as they disappear
one-by-one and had great feedback so far.
Needless
to say, this method is quite costly. We hope to supplement the costs (currently,
approximately $1.25 / band) through private and corporate donations and
purchases by local business who believe in the Project and want to give them to
their workers.
Another
option we’ve considered is creating micro-business opportunities for local Tica
women, including our seamstresses. They would receive the bands from the
Collaborative, sell them to their community, and return 50% to the
Collaborative. Hopefully, growth will occur when word of this project spreads to
the surrounding areas and we are able to create opportunities like this in much
of Costa Rica.
How can you help?

We are launching this Indiegogo Campaign to ensure the continuation of this Project beyond our current pilot of 3,000 bands. The funds will cover material, printing, paying the seamstresses, and promotional material.  Our goal is to blanket this area with bands as best as we can.
column4: >We will return to Boston in July and hope to raise enough to leave the Collaborative with the resources to expand and sustain the project.

column1: Ideally, we'll catch the attention of a sponsor who will keep the project going until there are sidewalks and lights on all the roads around here.
We look forward to driving at night and seeing the road filled

column2: >This Project has been a great experience for our kids.  They have been involved with it from the beginning: visiting the homes of the seamstresses, watching and learning about the printing process, filling their suitcases with reflective tape and velcro, and brainstorming with us the various pieces of the puzzle. They are learning what it means to recognize a problem and know that they can be a part of a solution.
>Not only will our kids benefit from this project, but we are working with the high school coordinator at La Paz, our kids' school, to get the 11th and 12th grade students involved as well.

column1: If we are successful in this geographic area we hope to expand the project further.  Who knows, maybe with your help Proyecto Bandas Reflectantes will grow to cover the whole country, maybe even to other parts of Central America, and beyond.
We welcome your ideas, feedback, and suggestions.
Debbie, Eli, Noah, Tali, and Nava.

Here is a link to a blog article by Costa-Rica-Guide.com titled ""Walk WAY off to the wild side or it may be hazardous to your health"".  It describes the dangers of Costa Rican roads and tells the story of a tourist unlucky enough to hit a pedestrian.

","IntroductionPeople are dying and being severely injured on the dark streets of Costa Rica. Without streetlights or sidewalks people are forced to walk on the street within inches of passing motorists. Reflective arm and ankle bands are a simple, inexpensive solution to this pervasive problem as they help both the pedestrians and drivers. We have created a small, local Women's Collaborative where the woman hand-make and sell Reflective Safety Bands to their community, bringing light to the dark streets of Costa Rica.                         An iPhone photo with flash is an impressive example of how bright                  our Reflective Safety Bands are at night to an oncoming vehicle. About Us

We are a mom, dad, three kids, and (now) two dogs from Boston who moved to the rural, Pacific Coast of Costa Rica in July 2014, simply to see the world through a different lens. Our perspective of life certainly has changed in the short time we’ve lived here. Sure, we now know what it means to live with cows, howler monkeys, chickens, street dogs, and countless varieties of reptiles at our front door. We also now understand why Ticos (the name Costa Rican's call themselves) were recently named the ""Happiest People on Earth.""  Finally, living here has illuminated  how easy it is to take for granted the privileges we have in the US, where our tax dollars ensure the safety and security of our public spaces and residents.  The Challenge

Road-related fatalities rank fourth in causes of death in Costa Rica. There are three times more pedestrian fatalities than alcohol related accidents in Costa Rica. Being on the roads at night is a dangerous and scary experience for pedestrians and motorists.  It gets dark here by 6:30 pm every night of the year and it's very hard to see what's ahead.  The roads are narrow,  have no sidewalks, and rarely have any street lights. Nevertheless, the road is the only place to walk.  Jungle on both sides or fear of snakes in the brush keeps everyone on the road. Only 18% of age-eligible drivers have a driver’s license. The rest travel by bus, bike, moto, or walk and many assume that because they can see the oncoming cars bright headlights, that the drivers can see them  … but they can’t.

Our friend Keith who lost his leg in a roadside accident.Debbie had the fortune of spending a week with Keith at a TEFL Training last year where they were certified to teach English as a second language.  Keith was in the training to acquire new skills because he was no longer able to do his previous job. Eighteen months earlier, he was hit by a car at 5:00 am while leaving work in Tamarindo and lost his leg.  He was lucky enough to meet a very generous expat who sponsored his recovery (and TEFL training) and arranged for him to be fitted and treated for a prosthetic leg. Needless to say, this support is not typical of others who have been injured on the local roads. Keith is super supportive of this project and excited to be able to offer the bands to his community. Our goal of this project is to prevent others, like Keith, from being hurt on these dark roads.The Solution:

Shortly after we moved here, Eli conceived of the idea to create and distribute reflective bands for the people living in the surrounding area.  We are now making this idea a reality.  There are about 3,000 residents in the surrounding towns (Potrero, Flamingo, Brasalito, Huacus, Villa Real, and Matapalo).  We have purchased enough reflective material from the States for a first run of 3,000 bands. Thanks to an introduction by Laetitia Deweer, founder of CEPIA, www.cepiacostarica.org, an incredible non-profit community center here, we have teamed up with some amazing women in the surrounding area, allowing us to start: Proyecto Bandas Reflectantes: Collaboration de Mujeres / Project Reflective Safety Bands: A Women’s Collaborative.      Meet the people who are making it happen:These four women have already made almost all 3,000 bands. They are grateful to have this earning opportunity and proud to be contributing from the beginning to a project that will directly impact their community. Listen to Thais' video in the Gallery above (in Spanish).
Meet the founding members of our Women’s Collaborative:                                   (From left to right) Ana, Olga, Auyda, and Thais.

Alfonso at HangTen, a local print-shop, has been super helpful in putting instructional information and photos on the bands.  The inside of the bands have photos with and without light and explain: ""Drivers can't see you until they are too close. This band reflects light back to the driver from far away. Wear it on your  wrist or ankle."" The band also has a local WhatsApp number and email encouraging questions, feedback ... and hopefully a request for more bands.                                          Debbie and Talia at Hang10 which is printing instructions                                                      on the inside of the bands.
Noah and Nava at Thais's sewing machine.              On March 8th, the women threw a surprise birthday party for Debbie.
Distribution Challenge -
We
have wrestled with how to distribute the Reflective Safety Bands and track the
impact they have on the roads. After much consultation, trial and error, our
initial plan is to give them away for free at the local markets, churches,
schools, on the streets, etc. We have created explanatory displays in English
and Spanish with rings of 40-60 bands attached and have hung them in many bus
stops, markets, and popular road-side areas. We’ve watched as they disappear
one-by-one and had great feedback so far.
Needless
to say, this method is quite costly. We hope to supplement the costs (currently,
approximately $1.25 / band) through private and corporate donations and
purchases by local business who believe in the Project and want to give them to
their workers.
Another
option we’ve considered is creating micro-business opportunities for local Tica
women, including our seamstresses. They would receive the bands from the
Collaborative, sell them to their community, and return 50% to the
Collaborative. Hopefully, growth will occur when word of this project spreads to
the surrounding areas and we are able to create opportunities like this in much
of Costa Rica.
How can you help?

We are launching this Indiegogo Campaign to ensure the continuation of this Project beyond our current pilot of 3,000 bands. The funds will cover material, printing, paying the seamstresses, and promotional material.  Our goal is to blanket this area with bands as best as we can. We will return to Boston in July and hope to raise enough to leave the Collaborative with the resources to expand and sustain the project.
Ideally, we'll catch the attention of a sponsor who will keep the project going until there are sidewalks and lights on all the roads around here.
We look forward to driving at night and seeing the road filled                                        with these shining Reflective Safety Bands.

This Project has been a great experience for our kids.  They have been involved with it from the beginning: visiting the homes of the seamstresses, watching and learning about the printing process, filling their suitcases with reflective tape and velcro, and brainstorming with us the various pieces of the puzzle. They are learning what it means to recognize a problem and know that they can be a part of a solution.
Not only will our kids benefit from this project, but we are working with the high school coordinator at La Paz, our kids' school, to get the 11th and 12th grade students involved as well.

If we are successful in this geographic area we hope to expand the project further.  Who knows, maybe with your help Proyecto Bandas Reflectantes will grow to cover the whole country, maybe even to other parts of Central America, and beyond.
We welcome your ideas, feedback, and suggestions.
Debbie, Eli, Noah, Tali, and Nava.

  This is Carolyn, my truly amazing grandmother and a woman I want to surprise this Christmas with a vacation to Virginia to not only see her son and two other grandchildren for the first time all together in many years but, to actually get to spend the holiday AND her birthday with them. Everyday, she tells me how much she wants to be able to pick up and go to them but, unfortunately, can't afford to do so. This is how I try to somehow pay her back in such a small way for ALL that she has done for me. Let me tell you a little bit about that.
  I moved into my grandmothers house when I was 15 and through the past 10 years, this woman has been absolutely everything to me. She not only watched me finally come into my own but, she helped me get there. Around 16-20, I had fallen in and out of severe depression and struggled with handling it. She was constantly there for me through all of that, for every near suicide attempt, every breakdown, falter, misstep, and apathetic episode-- she was there. She has guided me through my highs and lows, been the mother I never had, and the best friend I always needed. She'll be yours, too, if you want!! I am proof of how good she is, not just to myself but, to everyone around her and I reach every single day to have that kind of compassion, love, and respect for the people around me.
  Unfortunately, living with her for the past 10 years, I've had to witness her lows just as she did mine and she isn't coming up from hers as gracefully. A few years ago, she retired after having quadruple bypass surgery which was quickly followed by her husband losing his job. I have helped as much as I could but, I don't make enough working in retail to help as much as I want. Since declaring bankrupcty and my grandfather since having a new job, they are slowly getting back to stable ground, which testifies to her can-do spirit I only hope grows stronger within me.
for all that she has been through, all that she has done, all that she is, I want to completely surprise her with the one thing she has wanted for the past 10 years- to spend the Christmas with her son and other two grandchildren in Virginia. I can't do this all on my own and I sincerely hope you guys can help me give someone who deserves so much, something so small.

I will be offering perks for donations which can be found below! If you'd like a look at what you'll be getting, you can view it all on Instagram @chinaskibird

For all who help me give his to her, I am eternal grateful and forever love you!

At the core of this campaign, is the artist himself. I had the pleasure to befriend Santos, and his unwavering optimism, love for all people, passion for life, and love of art has affected me and everyone he meets deeply. Help us to bring Santos' work to the U.S. To learn more about Santos please send a message and I'll be happy to answer all questions. He has a truly moving life story. He has had a dream to bring his work to the USA since he began this project years ago. This is not intended as a one-time deal, but the beginning of a business with the intention of bringing enough income to Santos through art and fashion that he can do this full-time as his career. Help us make that dream a reality! 

Products Planned for 2017:

- Shoulder bags

- Fabric covered greeting cards

- Keychains

- Bead bracelets

- Converse style shoes covered with African fabric (Santos' specialty)

Below is Santos' story in his own words.

by Santos

""I'm a young man of 30 years, originally from Benin and currently living in Ghana. I grew up in a family of 5. Growing up I've always had passion for art and fashion, it has actually been something my parents were doing as well. But I always think of expanding it and make it known worldwide, how African art is beautiful. 

In 2007 I left my country to Ivory Coast still pursuing my dream of art and fashion. I later came to Ghana in 2014 and met lovely people whom also have a passion for art. Art has basically been part of me since my childhood, and getting a big order will mean a lot to me and my family and I know it will change my life as well. And I will finally live my dream of being in the world of fashion and art.""

Ello Raw
www.elloraw.com
The Story:
<ul>
<li><span style=""background-color: initial
column2: >My name is Rebecca Holmes and I am a senior at Duke University studying Dance, Markets &amp
column3: Management and Education. I grew up in Lancaster, Pennsylvania in a family that struggled with mental and physical health issues. I realized that the food we were eating was affecting our lives and I wanted a world where all food was accessible, healthy and good for you.

column1: <li><span style=""background-color: initial
column2: >This past summer, as a fellow in the Melissa &amp
column3: Doug Entrepreneurs program at Duke, I sought out to create a healthy product but wasn't sure exactly what.

column1: <li><span style=""background-color: initial
column2: >In June, my two sisters and my brother-in-law went to spend a few days at the beach. While there we saw a Raw Vegan Cafe along the boardwalk and I forced my family into the doors so that I could try some things! I had been exploring raw foods around that time period and was excited to see what they had. My sister bought a few raw vegan donut holes and let my brother-in-law try one. He took a bite and raised his eyebrows, ""...this actually isn't bad, you should sell these"" and he proceeded to eat the entire thing, That was the moment I realized I had found something that was incredibly healthy, yet truly delicious. If my soda drinking, steak eating brother-in-law loved it then it must be a winner!

column1: <li><span style=""background-color: initial
column2: >After the trip I began recipe testing and created Ello Raw to put more real, delicious foods on our grocery shelves and in our bodies!

column1: <div>
The Product:
<ul>
<li>
Ello Raw has 3 varieties of dessert bites that come three in a pack: Goji Cacao Brownie, Coconut Chocolate Chip Cookie Dough and Cinnamon Sugar Donut
• All bites are dairy-free, gluten-free, non-gmo, organic, agave-free and egg-free!

• Desserts are normally filled with processed sugar that is horrible for our bodies. However, when I first started searching for a healthy dessert alternative without the sugar, I found nothing. Most desserts that claim to be healthy still list some sugar as one of their first ingredients. Agave is a huge fad right now among healthy, and especially raw foods, but research shows that it is no better than high fructose corn syrup and still spikes your blood sugar in an unhealthy way. In our Ello Raw bites we use NO AGAVE. We rely mostly on the natural sweetness of dates. Two of our varieties also use a small amount of raw honey, which amazingly is the only natural sweetener that has other healing and health benefits. The last ""sugar"" we use is a coconut palm sugar which is simply a dusting on our Cinnamon Sugar Donut variety. We want to pull the focus away from sugar and onto whole foods!
<div>
What We Have Accomplished so far:
<ul>
<li>
• Started in June 2014
• Recipes created, tested and finalized in July 2014
• Rice’s Market (successful market test) in late August of 2014
• Licensed and Established in Durham, NC in mid October of 2014
• Official member of the Cookery, commercial kitchen, in mid October 2014
• Began online orders at the end of November 2014
Our Goals and Vision
<ul>
• Currently we are working on securing retailers to carry our product. We want to have 20 retail partners by April 2015
• In the future we want to secure a working space that is certified Gluten-Free so that we can better accommodate our customers
• We hope to receive official certifications about the ingredients in our products so that we can provide assurance to our customers
• We also hope to expand into a place where we will be able to partner with local schools to provide a better dessert option in their cafeterias
• We know that education is just as important as our product and we hope to provide information on raw foods and health to all of our customers
Where Will the Funds Go?
<ul>
<li><span style=""background-color: initial
column2: >Every time we produce we pay for ingredients, packaging, labels and kitchen space. As we secure retailers and larger orders we will use the funds to support the production of orders and building inventory to support retail sales

column1: <li><span style=""background-color: initial
column2: >As a small start-up we've built ourselves with very little resources and there is much need for improvement. We will use some funds for the branding and marketing necessary to support expansion and our startup

column1: <li>
<span style=""background-color: initial
column2: >It is important that customers know our credibility and the authenticity of our ingredients. We will be using funds to secure health certifications such as USDA Organic and gluten-free which can be very expensive

column1: <li><span style=""background-color: initial
column2: >A small amount of the funds will go to nutrition testing where we will have our product analyzed to provide better information on the micro and macro nutrients

column1: <li><span style=""background-color: initial
column2:
>If we raise enough funds we will be looking into securing a certified Gluten-Free facility to better accommodate those with allergies


What You Get

The Perks

  • Donate anything and receive satisfaction knowing you helped a small startup begin!

column1: • Donate $10 and receive a personal thank you note
• Donate $25 and receive a 3-pack of dessert bites (you choose the flavors)
• Donate $100 and receive a years supply of Ello Raw dessert bites

• Donate $1000 and work individually with the founder to create your very own flavor of Ello Raw dessert bites. You will receive the entire first batch and If others like it we may make it our 4th variety!
Other Ways You Can Help
• Get the word out! Tell your friends about our campaign!

• Like us on Facebook and Follow us on Instagram. 
  • You can also share this campaign using Indiegogo share tools

www.elloraw.com
The Story:

My name is Rebecca Holmes and I am a senior at Duke University studying Dance, Markets & Management and Education. I grew up in Lancaster, Pennsylvania in a family that struggled with mental and physical health issues. I realized that the food we were eating was affecting our lives and I wanted a world where all food was accessible, healthy and good for you.
This past summer, as a fellow in the Melissa & Doug Entrepreneurs program at Duke, I sought out to create a healthy product but wasn't sure exactly what.

In June, my two sisters and my brother-in-law went to spend a few days at the beach. While there we saw a Raw Vegan Cafe along the boardwalk and I forced my family into the doors so that I could try some things! I had been exploring raw foods around that time period and was excited to see what they had. My sister bought a few raw vegan donut holes and let my brother-in-law try one. He took a bite and raised his eyebrows, ""...this actually isn't bad, you should sell these"" and he proceeded to eat the entire thing, That was the moment I realized I had found something that was incredibly healthy, yet truly delicious. If my soda drinking, steak eating brother-in-law loved it then it must be a winner!
After the trip I began recipe testing and created Ello Raw to put more real, delicious foods on our grocery shelves and in our bodies!
The Product:
Ello Raw has 3 varieties of dessert bites that come three in a pack: Goji Cacao Brownie, Coconut Chocolate Chip Cookie Dough and Cinnamon Sugar Donut
All bites are dairy-free, gluten-free, non-gmo, organic, agave-free and egg-free!

Desserts are normally filled with processed sugar that is horrible for our bodies. However, when I first started searching for a healthy dessert alternative without the sugar, I found nothing. Most desserts that claim to be healthy still list some sugar as one of their first ingredients. Agave is a huge fad right now among healthy, and especially raw foods, but research shows that it is no better than high fructose corn syrup and still spikes your blood sugar in an unhealthy way. In our Ello Raw bites we use NO AGAVE. We rely mostly on the natural sweetness of dates. Two of our varieties also use a small amount of raw honey, which amazingly is the only natural sweetener that has other healing and health benefits. The last ""sugar"" we use is a coconut palm sugar which is simply a dusting on our Cinnamon Sugar Donut variety. We want to pull the focus away from sugar and onto whole foods!
What We Have Accomplished so far:
Started in June 2014
Recipes created, tested and finalized in July 2014
Rice’s Market (successful market test) in late August of 2014
Licensed and Established in Durham, NC in mid October of 2014
Official member of the Cookery, commercial kitchen, in mid October 2014
Began online orders at the end of November 2014
Our Goals and Vision
Currently we are working on securing retailers to carry our product. We want to have 20 retail partners by April 2015
In the future we want to secure a working space that is certified Gluten-Free so that we can better accommodate our customers
We hope to receive official certifications about the ingredients in our products so that we can provide assurance to our customers
We also hope to expand into a place where we will be able to partner with local schools to provide a better dessert option in their cafeterias
We know that education is just as important as our product and we hope to provide information on raw foods and health to all of our customers
Where Will the Funds Go?

Every time we produce we pay for ingredients, packaging, labels and kitchen space. As we secure retailers and larger orders we will use the funds to support the production of orders and building inventory to support retail sales

As a small start-up we've built ourselves with very little resources and there is much need for improvement. We will use some funds for the branding and marketing necessary to support expansion and our startup

It is important that customers know our credibility and the authenticity of our ingredients. We will be using funds to secure health certifications such as USDA Organic and gluten-free which can be very expensive
A small amount of the funds will go to nutrition testing where we will have our product analyzed to provide better information on the micro and macro nutrients

If we raise enough funds we will be looking into securing a certified Gluten-Free facility to better accommodate those with allergies     What You Get The Perks  Donate anything and receive satisfaction knowing you helped a small startup begin!
Donate $10 and receive a personal thank you note
Donate $25 and receive a 3-pack of dessert bites (you choose the flavors)
Donate $100 and receive a years supply of Ello Raw dessert bites

Donate $1000 and work individually with the founder to create your very own flavor of Ello Raw dessert bites. You will receive the entire first batch and If others like it we may make it our 4th variety!
Other Ways You Can Help
Get the word out! Tell your friends about our campaign!
Like us on Facebook and Follow us on Instagram.  You can also share this campaign using Indiegogo share tools",1.0,0,"1 Campaign
|","Durham, United States",https://www.indiegogo.com/projects/ello-raw/pica

Suman's
family live near Nuwakot, a heritage site, NW of Kathmandu, about 40 km or so
from the epicentre. His family are alive but his mum was badly
injured when she had to jump from their home as it was falling down. Their
family home is rubble. His cousin was buried when his home collapsed but they
managed to dig him out. He is seriously injured and is being looked after in

hospital in Kathmandu.

We need to raise as much money as
possible in order to help Suman's family and village, where 18 out of the 24 houses in the village are now rubble and those families

homeless.

Suman's family, which includes his parents and the families of 3 of his brothers, have been sleeping under a tarpaulin since the first major earthquake. This is the same for the other homeless families whose homes are now rubble. Driven by the urgency of the situation as the Monsoon rains have started, some have managed to build a temporary shelter out of corrugated iron they have salvaged from the rubble and timber they have chopped from the forest. Some are still under tarpaulin. Suman is returning to Nepal this week with a shipment of donated tents and sleeping bags. He will be able to assess their needs but from talking to his family and other friends in the village so far it seems that some of your money will be best spent on essentials including:

a) any ongoing medical treatment for those who were injured,

b) water and food for people and animals, and kerosene stoves,

c) a few solar / windup lamps and torches for those under canvas.

Then the majority of your money will be spent on:

d) materials and labour for building more temporary shelters for people and their harvest,

And if any is left over then:

e) a contribution to building materials for more permanent homes.

We promise to use your money wisely and we will keep a record of everything spent.

Thankyou

******UPDATE****** We have raised $10,000 OUTSIDE of this campaign!!!

What better way to get this project off the ground other than a community crowd-funding campaign? That is what we’re all about! We have the vision and you have the money to bring the vision to fruition. Team-work!

You will be paying for membership once the studio opens anyways, so why not put the investment in now to secure your spot?

We are so blessed to live in such a beautiful location (I hear it’s one of the nicest, if not THE nicest neighborhood IN THE WORLD). It’s so beautiful, what could possibly make it better? A community space that is family-friendly, multi-functional, high-vibrational, and conscious. If it were a vegetable it would definitely be organic. If it was meat it would definitely be from The Village Butcher (No, we’re not vegan, but it’s okay if you are!)

We have the ocean, nature, farmers markets, juice-bars, health-food stores, healers of all varieties, and yes, we have the yoga studios. But what about a place to come together to express consciously, authentically, and creatively?

 

The Visionary

Hi, I’m Kendra and I would love to meet you in person for real (and I'm sure we will meet soon enough), but for now, technology is here for us. I also go by Chandra Lokah, a name given to me while I was in Peru in 2014.

After I graduated university with a degree in International Relations I didn’t know what to do with myself. During university I worked as a waitress and snowboarded. As I learned more about the realities of the world I developed severe anxiety. What I didn’t realize was that I had in fact always suffered with anxiety. I was so unaware that I thought what I was feeling was just normal.

I was into health food so I decided to study holistic nutrition. When I completed the course I went on to study herbal medicine. This was the beginning of my passion for holistic and preventative health.

Half way through the herbal medicine course I broke my foot. Two months later I broke my back. Two months later I broke my toe. (Which one do you think hurt the most?)

I won’t go too deeply into detail here. All you have to know is that after feeling so much pain I set a strong intention to do everything possible to stop the cycle. This is what led me to deepen my yoga and meditation practice, become a teacher, and eventually come out of anxiety and into self-love and inner-peace.

Since then I’ve explored both the outer and inner world through travel, spiritual practices, art, shamanic medicine, sensory deprivation chambers, community gatherings, music, reading, writing, and numerous courses. I have a passion for holistic lifestyle, community, and self-healing.

And that is why I am so passionate about Oak Bay Yoga. It is more than a yoga studio. It is a whole-life space where you, your friends, your family, and the greater community can learn, share, grow, love, laugh, sing, dance, play, draw, paint, move…or just ""be"" and breathe…together.

Although I have the vision, there are many people behind-the-scenes helping to manifest this vision. Collaboration is what Oak Bay Yoga is all about. Have an idea you’d like to share? I’m all ears!

What You Get

You have the choice to receive studio membership, unlimited yoga membership (1 month, 3 month, 6 month, 1 year), individual classes, holistic massage, deep tissue massage, etc.

Classes offered include gentle, hatha, flow, restorative, yin, child, and family-friendly yoga, as well as Qi Gong, Acro Yoga, and Yoga Nidra. Times will range from early morning to evening classes. Events will include dances, art nights, open-mic poetry/music, and workshops.

I was trained in the Kripalu lineage, which centers around inward-focus and taking yoga off-the-mat as a lifestyle - but we still love the ""on-the-mat"" yoga as well! We will have a variety of teachers each bringing their own style and gifts.

What We Need

First and foremost we need funding for rent, which is about $2600/month. (ALREADY PAID FOR!)

Once we secure the lease we will need to do some renovations to ensure the space is ready to serve the community most efficiently and beautifully.
• Flooring and installation - ~$4500 (ALREADY PAID FOR!)
• Curtains - ~$200
• Shelving - ~$500
• Furniture - ~$500
• Handicap washroom installation - (ALREADY PAID FOR!)
Other start-up costs include:
• Yoga props - ~$3000
• Kangen Water System - $1000+
• Miscellaneous - ~$1000+ – This includes things like cleaning supplies, insurance, office supplies, and all the other fun stuff that keeps a business running!

With first months rent plus renovations and other start-up costs that brings us to ~$13,500. I’ve set the goal at $15,000 for a little wiggle-room, as there are always unexpected costs. But with large items already taken care of we've made it to ~$10,000 OUTSIDE of the campaign already!

The Impact

“Don’t ask what the world needs. Ask what makes you come alive, and go do it. Because what the world needs is people who have come alive.” – Howard Thurman


A tentative bare-boned schedule for the studio is as follows:

4:30-6:00am – Silent Practice*

6-7am – Rise-and-Shine Yoga

7:15-7:45am – Morning Meditation*

8-9 – Private Yoga and Massage

9:15-10:30 – Rotating yoga/pilates classes

10:30-1 – Community time

1-4pm – Private Yoga and Massage

4-5pm – rotating yoga classes

5:15-6:30 – Evening Yoga

6:30-7 – Evening Meditation*

~7-9 – Event (Dance, art, music, spoken-word, workshop, etc)*

All classes are all ages and all levels except 4:30-6:15am silent practice. This is for more advanced practitioners who can self-guide their own practice. During this time we will join together in the space to move and breathe in silence.

* events are included in studio memberships - $100/yr or $12/month (which will also include other perks such as 10% participating stores, store merch, and participating healing therapies)

 

All vacant times may be rented out to practitioners, teachers, or others who would like to host a conscious event.

All other vacant time will be open to members to come use the space to practice, read, have tea, or share a conversation.

Risks &
column2:
Challenges

At this point in time there are many supportive community members excited to be a part of the Oak Bay Yoga team through programs such as Karma Yoga. This is an exchange of time worked for complimentary yoga.

A potential risk is that these individuals become to busy with school or work and are unable to continue to help out at the studio. To solve these challenges we will always be open to talking with different people about these opportunities. If right now you are interested, please get in touch.

Other Ways You Can Help

Some people have extra money to spare, and others don’t. If you don’t, that doesn’t mean you get get involved and help out in other ways.

One way you can make a contribution is by sharing the campaign with your friends, family, and social media platforms. There are even share tools on Indiegogo for your convenience.

Another way you can contribute is if you have any skills that would benefit the studio in any way.
